title: Domain 3.2: Given a scenario, apply security principles to secure enterprise infrastructure.
content:
🧱 Infrastructure Considerations (Part 1)

📍 Device Placement

Strategically position firewalls, sensors, and servers to maximize protection and monitoring coverage.

🧭 Security Zones

Use segmented network areas (DMZ, internal, guest) with unique trust levels to limit access and isolate risks.

🎯 Attack Surface

Minimize exposure points where attackers can interact with your systems or extract data.

🔗 Connectivity

Ensure secure protocols, cable integrity, and firewall rules for safe system communication.

⚠️ Failure Modes

  • 🟢 Fail-Open: Allows traffic if a system fails—less secure, maintains availability.
  • 🔴 Fail-Closed: Blocks all traffic on failure—more secure but may disrupt services.

⚙️ Device Attributes

  • ⚡ Active: Responds to threats (e.g., blocks them).
  • Passive: Observes only, does not intervene.
  • 🧪 Inline: Directly in traffic flow—can block threats.
  • Tap/Monitor: Watches traffic without interference—used for logging or detection.

🧩 Network Appliances

  • 🚪 Jump Server: Secure gateway to reach isolated devices.
  • 🕵️ Proxy Server: Forwards requests, enforces access control, hides internal IPs.
  • 🛡️ IDS: Alerts on suspicious activity—does not block.
  • 🛡️ IPS: Detects and blocks malicious traffic.
  • ⚖️ Load Balancer: Distributes traffic to improve performance and redundancy.

🔌 Port Security

  • 🧷 802.1X: Authenticates devices before they join a network.
  • 🧩 EAP: Supports various authentication methods within 802.1X.

🔥 Firewall Types

  • 🌐 WAF: Filters HTTP/S traffic—blocks common web attacks.
  • 🛠️ UTM: Bundles firewall, AV, IDS/IPS, etc.—all-in-one security.
  • 🚀 NGFW: Deep inspection + app filtering—advanced protection.
  • 🎚️ Layer 4: Filters by IP, port, protocol.
  • Layer 7: Filters based on app content (e.g., DNS, HTTP).

🔐 Secure Communication/Access

  • 🌐 VPN: Encrypted tunnel for private remote access.
  • 💼 Remote Access: External connections with strict control (VPN + MFA).
  • 🛣️ Tunneling: Encapsulation method for secure transmission.
  • 🔒 TLS: Encrypts data over HTTP, email, etc.
  • 🛡️ IPSec: Secures IP traffic—often used in VPNs.

🧠 Advanced Access Models

  • 🛰️ SD-WAN: Routes traffic over multiple WANs—more efficient + centralized control.
  • 🛡️ SASE: Combines SD-WAN with security tools delivered from the cloud (ZTNA, CASB, FWaaS).

🎯 Selection of Effective Controls

Pick controls (technical, admin, physical) that align with business needs, environment, and risk—builds defense-in-depth.
